IEEE CASE 2025 Student Hackathon

Generative AI & Digital Twins: Transforming Advanced Manufacturing



Background

This hackathon event offers students and engineering practitioners a unique opportunity to explore how data science and machine learning techniques can be applied to solve real-world engineering problems. The theme for this year is Generative AI & Digital Twins: Transforming Advanced Manufacturing.

IEEE CASE will host its first-ever hackathon at the IEEE CASE Conference in a hybrid format—featuring both virtual and on-site components—as part of the workshop day on August 17, 2025.

Biltmore Hotel Downtown Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA
August 10–16, 2025 (Virtual) & August 17, 2025 (In-Person)
In conjunction with
IEEE CASE Conference (August 17–21, 2025, In-Person)
Sponsored by
IEEE CASE, Stantec, and National Cheng Kung University

Please register for the hackathon via the conference registration link: [Registration Link] .

This will be a hybrid event—both virtual and on-site—so you can choose your preferred participation method during the registration process. Note that you do not need to register for the full conference in order to join the hackathon.
Please also email us at hyunwoong.ko@asu.edu so we can connect with you virtually. For in-person participants, there is a suggested limit on the number of attendees, and spots will be filled on a first-come, first-served basis. For virtual-only participants, there is no limit on the number of attendees.

*By registering for the Hackathon, you agree to allow your information to be shared with other registrants and volunteer leaders for the purpose of event communication and intrateam coordination.

Important Dates:

August 10, 2025, Virtual Hackathon Kick-off
August 17, 2025, Hybrid Hackathon Closing
  • Hackathon Deliverables Submission
  • Workshop provided by the organizing team
  • Final Presentations
  • Hackathon Judging
  • Closing Ceremony
    •

Award

A total of approximately $2,000 in prizes will be awarded for:

  • First Prize
  • Second prize
  • Third prize
  • MEME Challenge
Note: Teams will be judged, and awardees will be selected accordingly.

Eligibility

Undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and non-students (e.g., professionals) are welcome to participate in the Hackathon and experience the excitement of the competition.

Team and Presentation

  • All participants must be registered. Everyone will be placed on a team of 2–3 members. You may form a team based on your own preference. All implementations must be original work.
  • Each Hackathon team will continue their collaboration independently using their chosen communication platform between August 10, 2025, and August 17, 2025.
  • Each team is required to present their work, including their technical approach, and submit the results to their own GitHub repository by the submission deadline.
  • Final presentations, results, and technical approaches will be evaluated by a technical committee (separate from the Hackathon organizing committee).

Problem Statement

Full problem statement document
Laser Powder Bed Fusion (LPBF) is a leading metal additive manufacturing (AM) technology valued for its ability to fabricate complex, high-performance components. However, the process remains vulnerable to defects that compromise part quality and repeatability. One of the most critical—and often overlooked—sources of such defects is the powder spreading step, where anomalies like streaks or debris can lead to uneven powder layers and downstream printing issues.
Monitoring the layer-wise powder spreading conditions is essential to identify potential defects early in the printing process. As machine vision and data-driven methods become more capable, image-based inspection has become a promising tool to automate the quality control of powder spreading process. Still, challenges remain in robustly detecting anomalies under varying lighting and surface conditions, and in generating high-fidelity synthetic data to support model development.
This challenge invites participants to explore both: building models to segment powder spreading anomalies and generating realistic powder-bed images to enhance quality monitoring in LPBF.
*The full dataset will be made available to all participants at the beginning of the event.
